001package io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004import java.util.Arrays;
005
006import org.slf4j.Logger;
007import org.slf4j.LoggerFactory;
008
009import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonSubTypes;
010import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonSubTypes.Type;
011import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonTypeInfo;
012import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonTypeInfo.Id;
013import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.OptBoolean;
014
015import io.github.ai4ci.abm.Calibration;
016import io.github.ai4ci.abm.Outbreak;
017import io.github.ai4ci.abm.OutbreakBaseline;
018import io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost.InHostModelState;
019import io.github.ai4ci.config.PartialMarkovStateModel;
020import io.github.ai4ci.config.PartialPhenomenologicalModel;
021import io.github.ai4ci.config.PartialStochasticModel;
022import io.github.ai4ci.config.execution.ExecutionConfiguration;
023import io.github.ai4ci.functions.DelayDistribution;
024import io.github.ai4ci.functions.EmpiricalDistribution;
025import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
026
027/**
028 * Configuration for an in‑host model.
029 *
030 * <p>
031 * This interface is a common supertype for the various in‑host model
032 * configurations. It is used to allow the execution configuration to reference
033 * any in‑host model configuration, and to allow the initialiser to accept any
034 * in‑host model configuration. It also provides some common utility methods for
035 * working with in‑host models, such as calculating the infectivity profile and
036 * severity profile.
037 *
038 * <p>
039 * Downstream uses include the initialiser
040 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.DefaultInHostMarkovStateInitialiser}
041 * which accepts an instance of this interface to build an individual's in‑host
042 * state. It is also referenced by example code and tests.
043 *
044 * @author Rob Challen
045 */
046@JsonTypeInfo(
047                use = Id.NAME,
048                requireTypeIdForSubtypes = OptBoolean.TRUE
049)
050@JsonSubTypes(
051        { @Type(
052                        value = ImmutableStochasticModel.class,
053                        name = "stochastic"
054        ), @Type(value = ImmutablePhenomenologicalModel.class,
055                        name = "phenomenological"
056        ), @Type(value = ImmutableMarkovStateModel.class,
057                        name = "markov"
058        ), @Type(value = PartialStochasticModel.class,
059                        name = "stochastic.modifier"
060        ), @Type(value = PartialPhenomenologicalModel.class,
061                        name = "phenomenological.modifier"
062        ), @Type(value = PartialMarkovStateModel.class,
063                        name = "markov.modifier"
064        ) }
065)
066public interface InHostConfiguration extends Serializable {
067
068        /** logger for this class */
069        static Logger log = LoggerFactory.getLogger(InHostConfiguration.class);
070
071        /**
072         * The limit is the point at which the tail of the distribution is cut off.
073         * This is used to trim the infectivity profile and the severity profile to
074         * the point where 99.9% of transmission or severity has occurred. This is
075         * not critical as long as it is high enough to capture the full profile, but
076         * not too high to be inefficient. The profiles are trimmed to the point
077         * where 99.9% of transmission or severity has occurred, so this is not
078         * critical as long as it is high enough to capture the full profile, but not
079         * too high to be inefficient.
080         */
081        static final double LIMIT = 0.999;
082
083        /**
084         * Calculate the infectivity profile from a viral load profile and a
085         * transmission parameter.
086         *
087         * <p>
088         * This is used to calculate the infectivity profile from the viral load
089         * profile calculated by
090         * {@link #getViralLoadProfile(ExecutionConfiguration, int, int)}, which is
091         * used to calibrate the transmission parameter to get the desired R0, and to
092         * calculate the infectivity profile. It is not used directly in the model,
093         * which calculates transmission from the viral load of each individual
094         * agent. The profile is trimmed to the point where 99.9% of transmission has
095         * occurred, so this is not critical as long as it is long enough.
096         *
097         * @param viralLoad             the viral load profile to use to calculate
098         *                              the infectivity profile.
099         * @param transmissionParameter the transmission parameter to use to
100         *                              calculate the infectivity profile.
101         * @return the infectivity profile calculated from the viral load profile and
102         *         the transmission parameter.
103         */
104        public static DelayDistribution getInfectivityProfile(
105                        double[][] viralLoad, double transmissionParameter
106        ) {
107
108                int samples = viralLoad.length;
109                int duration = viralLoad[0].length;
110
111                double[][] trans = transmissionFromLoad(viralLoad, transmissionParameter);
112                // Sample (1st dimension: samples wise ) average to get transmission
113                // probability array
114                double[] meanTrans = new double[duration];
115                for (int i = 0; i < duration; i++) {
116                        for (int n = 0; n < samples; n++) {
117                                meanTrans[i] += trans[n][i] / samples;
118                        }
119                }
120                DelayDistribution tmp = DelayDistribution.unnormalised(
121                                DelayDistribution.trimTail(meanTrans, 1 - LIMIT, false)
122                );
123                log.debug(
124                                "Serial interval " + LIMIT + " limit: " + tmp.size()
125                                                + "; mean duration: " + tmp.expected()
126                );
127                return tmp;
128        }
129
130        /**
131         * Derived distribution determined by in host viral load model and overall
132         * transmission rate required to get desired R0. <br>
133         * <br>
134         *
135         * Infectivity profile assumes a contact has occurred and it is the
136         * conditional probability of transmission on that day versus any other
137         * particular day. This is controlled in real life by things like symptoms
138         * and behaviour, but in theory that is controlled for by the condition that
139         * transmission has occurred. This is the difference between the generation
140         * time, and the effective generation time, and parallels R0 and Rt. This is
141         * effectively G0 not Gt, and is determined only by the average viral load in
142         * a naive host, following a standard exposure.
143         *
144         * There is a question as to whether the infectivity profile is solely
145         * dependent on viral load, or there is an element of contact behaviour in
146         * here as well. If the latter then repeated contacts would make viral load a
147         * hazard function of generation time, as people with multiple exposures
148         * eventually get infected. This would tend to make the GT look shorter than
149         * the infectious period.
150         *
151         * The infectivity profile is the calibrated transmission probability for the
152         * average case conditioned on a transmission occurring. Although this is
153         * calculated it is not really used internally, except to calculate an
154         * estimate of $R_t$, and to define the true length of the infective period.
155         *
156         * @param execConfig            the configuration to get the viral load
157         *                              profile for. This is used to get the in host
158         *                              configuration, but also to get the infection
159         *                              case rate, hospitalisation rate and fatality
160         *                              rate to calculate the severity cutoffs for
161         *                              symptoms, hospitalisation and fatality by the
162         *                              downstream class {@link Calibration}.
163         * @param transmissionParameter the transmission parameter to use to
164         *                              calculate the infectivity profile. This
165         * @param samples               the number of samples to use to get the
166         *                              average profile. This should be large enough
167         *                              to get a stable estimate of the profile, but
168         *                              not too large to be inefficient. The profile
169         *                              is trimmed to the point where 99.9% of
170         *                              transmission has occurred, so this is not
171         *                              critical as long as it is large enough.
172         * @param duration              the number of time steps to calculate the
173         *                              profile for. This should be long enough to
174         *                              capture the full profile, but not too long to
175         *                              be inefficient. The profile is trimmed to the
176         *                              point where 99.9% of transmission has
177         *                              occurred, so this is not critical as long as
178         *                              it is long enough.
179         * @return a delay distribution with the average transmission probability at
180         *         each time post exposure, averaged across all agents, and
181         *         conditioned on a transmission occurring. The profile is trimmed to
182         *         the point where 99.9% of transmission has occurred, so this is not
183         *         critical as long as it is long enough.
184         *
185         */
186        public static DelayDistribution getInfectivityProfile(
187                        ExecutionConfiguration execConfig, double transmissionParameter,
188                        int samples, int duration
189        ) {
190                return getInfectivityProfile(
191                                getViralLoadProfile(execConfig, samples, duration),
192                                transmissionParameter
193                );
194        }
195
196        /**
197         * Determine the statistical distribution of maximum severity in a homogenous
198         * population, exposed with unit exposure. This is used to determine the
199         * severity cutoffs for symptoms, hospitalisation and fatality by the
200         * downstream class {@link Calibration}.
201         *
202         * @param config     the in host configuration to use to get the severity
203         *                   profile
204         * @param execConfig the execution configuration to use to get the severity
205         *                   profile. This is used to get the in host configuration,
206         *                   but also to get the infection case rate, hospitalisation
207         *                   rate and fatality rate to calculate the severity cutoffs
208         *                   for symptoms, hospitalisation and fatality by the
209         *                   downstream class {@link Calibration}.
210         * @param samples    the number of samples to use to get the empirical
211         *                   distribution.
212         * @param duration   the number of time steps to calculate the severity
213         *                   profile for. This should be long enough to capture the
214         *                   full profile, but not too long to be inefficient. The
215         *                   profile is trimmed to the point where 99.9% of severity
216         *                   has occurred, so this is not critical as long as it is
217         *                   long enough.
218         *
219         * @return an empirical distribution
220         */
221        public static EmpiricalDistribution getPeakSeverity(
222                        InHostConfiguration config, ExecutionConfiguration execConfig,
223                        int samples, int duration
224        ) {
225                Sampler rng = Sampler.getSampler();
226                double[] x = new double[samples];
227                for (int i = 0; i < samples; i++) {
228
229                        InHostModelState<?> state = InHostModelState
230                                        .test(config, execConfig, rng);
231                        double max = 0;
232                        state = state.update(rng, 1D, 0);
233                        for (int j = 0; j < duration; j++) {
234                                if (state.getNormalisedSeverity() > max) {
235                                        max = state.getNormalisedSeverity();
236                                }
237                                state = state.update(rng, 0, 0);
238                        }
239                        x[i] = max;
240                }
241
242                return EmpiricalDistribution.fromData(x);
243        }
244
245        /**
246         * Get the severity profile for a homogenous population, exposed with unit
247         * exposure. This is used to determine the severity cutoffs for symptoms,
248         * hospitalisation and fatality by the downstream class {@link Calibration}.
249         * The severity profile is the average severity at each time post exposure,
250         * averaged across all agents. The profile is trimmed to the point where
251         * 99.9% of severity has occurred, so this is not critical as long as it is
252         * long enough.
253         *
254         * @param execConfig the execution configuration to use to get the severity
255         *                   profile. This is used to get the in host configuration,
256         *                   but also to get the infection case rate, hospitalisation
257         *                   rate and fatality rate to calculate the severity cutoffs
258         *                   for symptoms, hospitalisation and fatality by the
259         *                   downstream class {@link Calibration}.
260         * @param samples    the number of samples to use to get the average profile.
261         *                   This should be large enough to get a stable estimate of
262         *                   the profile, but not too large to be inefficient. The
263         *                   profile is trimmed to the point where 99.9% of severity
264         *                   has occurred, so this is not critical as long as it is
265         *                   large enough.
266         * @param duration   the number of time steps to calculate the severity
267         *                   profile for. This should be long enough to capture the
268         *                   full profile, but not too long to be inefficient. The
269         *                   profile is trimmed to the point where 99.9% of severity
270         *                   has occurred, so this is not critical as long as it is
271         *                   long enough.
272         * @return a delay distribution with the average severity at each time post
273         *         exposure, averaged across all agents. The profile is trimmed to
274         *         the point where 99.9% of severity has occurred, so this is not
275         *         critical as long as it is long enough.
276         */
277        public static DelayDistribution getSeverityProfile(
278                        ExecutionConfiguration execConfig, int samples, int duration
279        ) {
280                InHostConfiguration config = execConfig.getInHostConfiguration();
281                Sampler rng = Sampler.getSampler();
282                double[] symptom = new double[duration];
283                for (int n = 0; n <= samples; n++) {
284
285                        InHostModelState<?> state = InHostModelState
286                                        .test(config, execConfig, rng);
287                        state = state.update(rng, 1D, 0D);
288                        for (int i = 0; i < duration; i++) {
289                                symptom[i] = symptom[i] + state.getNormalisedSeverity();
290                                state = state.update(rng, 0D, 0);
291                        }
292                }
293                double[] cumulative = new double[duration];
294
295                for (int i = 0; i < duration; i++) {
296                        symptom[i] = symptom[i] / samples;
297                        cumulative[i] = symptom[i] + (i == 0 ? 0 : cumulative[i - 1]);
298
299                }
300                int cutoff = 0;
301                double average = 0;
302                for (int i = 0; i < duration; i++) {
303                        if (cumulative[i] / cumulative[duration - 1] > LIMIT) {
304                                cutoff = i;
305
306                                break;
307                        }
308                        average += symptom[i] * i;
309                }
310                average = average / cutoff;
311                log.debug(
312                                "Symptom distribution " + LIMIT + " limit: " + cutoff
313                                                + "; mean duration: " + average
314                );
315                return DelayDistribution
316                                .unnormalised(Arrays.copyOfRange(symptom, 0, cutoff));
317        }
318
319        /**
320         * For a configuration gets an average viral load profile. This is used to
321         * calibrate the transmission parameter to get the desired R0, and to
322         * calculate the infectivity profile. It is not used directly in the model,
323         * which calculates transmission from the viral load of each individual
324         * agent.
325         *
326         * This is used downstream in classes like {@link OutbreakBaseline} to
327         * calculate the transmission parameter to get the desired R0, and to
328         * calculate the infectivity profile, and in {@link Calibration} to calculate
329         * the severity cutoffs.
330         *
331         * @param execConfig the configuration to get the viral load profile for
332         * @param samples    the number of samples to use to get the average profile.
333         * @param duration   the number of time steps to calculate the profile for.
334         *                   This should be long enough to capture the full profile,
335         *                   but not too long to be inefficient. The profile is
336         *                   trimmed to the point where 99.9% of transmission has
337         *                   occurred, so this is not critical as long as it is long
338         *                   enough.
339         *
340         * @return an array with sample as first dimension and time post exposure and
341         *         second dimension is the average viral load across all the agents
342         *         at that time post exposure
343         */
344        public static double[][] getViralLoadProfile(
345                        ExecutionConfiguration execConfig, int samples, int duration
346        ) {
347                // TODO: need to switch this to Stream<double[]> and calculate
348                // transmission
349                // from viral load for each profile separately because the average tends
350                // to under represent when cut off of 1 is applied later. Interestingly
351                // this probably is why it used to work as the cutoff was before
352                // averaging.
353                InHostConfiguration config = execConfig.getInHostConfiguration();
354
355                Sampler rng = Sampler.getSampler();
356                double[][] load = new double[samples][duration];
357                for (int n = 0; n < samples; n++) {
358                        InHostModelState<?> state = InHostModelState
359                                        .test(config, execConfig, rng);
360                        // viral exposure at t=0.
361                        // This is a standard unit dose.
362                        state = state.update(rng, 1D, 0);
363                        for (int i = 0; i < duration; i++) {
364                                load[n][i] = state.getNormalisedViralLoad();
365                                state = state.update(rng, 0, 0);
366                        }
367                }
368                return load;
369        }
370
371        private static double[][] transmissionFromLoad(
372                        double[][] viralLoad, double transmissionParameter
373        ) {
374                int samples = viralLoad.length;
375                int duration = viralLoad[0].length;
376                double[][] trans = new double[samples][duration];
377                for (int n = 0; n < samples; n++) {
378                        for (int i = 0; i < duration; i++) {
379                                trans[n][i] = OutbreakBaseline.transmissibilityFromViralLoad(
380                                                viralLoad[n][i], transmissionParameter
381                                );
382                        }
383                }
384                return trans;
385        }
386
387        /**
388         * The cutoff is the severity level above which people get fatal outcomes.
389         *
390         * <p>
391         * This is calibrated to get the desired infection fatality rate (IFR) for
392         * the outbreak. The IFR is the proportion of all infected people that get
393         * fatal outcomes, so it is the proportion of people above the cutoff.
394         *
395         * @param outbreak      the outbreak to get the severity cutoff for.
396         * @param configuration the execution configuration to get the severity
397         *                      cutoff for.
398         * @return the severity cutoff for fatality. This is the severity level above
399         *         which people get hospitalised, calibrated to get the desired
400         *         infection fatality rate (IFR) for the outbreak.
401         */
402        default double getSeverityFatalityCutoff(
403                        Outbreak outbreak, ExecutionConfiguration configuration
404        ) {
405                return Calibration.inferSeverityCutoff(
406                                outbreak, configuration.getInfectionFatalityRate()
407                );
408        }
409
410        /**
411         * The cutoff is the severity level above which people get hospitalised. This
412         * is calibrated to get the desired infection hospitalisation rate (IHR) for
413         * the outbreak. The IHR is the proportion of all infected people that get
414         * hospitalised, so it is the proportion of people above the cutoff. For
415         * example, if there are lets say 40% asymptomatic and case hosp rate of 10%.
416         * The IHR overall is 10% of the 60% symptomatic, so 6% The cutoff is the
417         * people that don;t get hospitalised so 94% quantile.
418         *
419         * @param outbreak      the outbreak to get the severity cutoff for. This is
420         *                      used to get the infection hospitalisation rate (IHR)
421         *                      to calibrate the cutoff to.
422         * @param configuration the execution configuration to get the severity
423         *                      cutoff for. This is used to
424         * @return the severity cutoff for hospitalisation. This is the severity
425         *         level above which people get hospitalised, calibrated to get the
426         *         desired infection hospitalisation rate (IHR) for the outbreak.
427         */
428        default double getSeverityHospitalisationCutoff(
429                        Outbreak outbreak, ExecutionConfiguration configuration
430        ) {
431                return Calibration.inferSeverityCutoff(
432                                outbreak, configuration.getInfectionHospitalisationRate()
433                );
434        }
435
436        /**
437         * The cutoff is the severity level above which people get symptoms. This is
438         * calibrated to get the desired infection case rate (ICR) for the outbreak.
439         * The ICR is the proportion of all infected people that get symptoms, so it
440         * is the proportion of people above the cutoff. For example, if there are
441         * lets say 40% asymptomatic, the cutoff is the 60% quantile.
442         *
443         * @param outbreak      the outbreak to get the severity cutoff for. This is
444         *                      used to get the infection case rate (ICR) to
445         *                      calibrate the cutoff to.
446         * @param configuration the execution configuration to get the severity
447         *                      cutoff for. This is used to get the infection case
448         *                      rate (ICR) to calibrate the cutoff to.
449         * @return the severity cutoff for symptoms. This is the severity level above
450         *         which people get symptoms, calibrated to get the desired infection
451         *         case rate (ICR) for the outbreak.
452         */
453        default double getSeveritySymptomsCutoff(
454                        Outbreak outbreak, ExecutionConfiguration configuration
455        ) {
456                return Calibration.inferSeverityCutoff(
457                                outbreak, configuration.getInfectionCaseRate()
458                );
459        }
460
461}
